Puckett's 8 bands you'll want to see this week

This week's top picks were selected by music writer Jeffrey Lee Puckett

Puckett's 8 bands you'll want to see this week

LCJ 1:20 p.m. EST November 5, 2014

James Taylor (Photo: James_O'Mara)

CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

James Taylor was long ago tossed into the soft-rock ghetto, dismissed as dad music and worse. There are admittedly some good reasons for this, but Taylor has always had a subtle eccentricity and when he's on, no one writes a better, more fully realized song.

WHEN: 8 p.m. Friday

WHERE: KFC Yum! Center

COST: $69, $89, available at the box office, online at www.ticketmaster.com and by phone, (800) 745-3000

Loretta Lynn (Photo: Provided)

Loretta Lynn will always be the queen of country music, no matter how many claim otherwise. A powerfully expressive singer and a songwriter who slings around honesty like a sledgehammer, Lynn is the epitome of down-home cool.

WHEN: 8 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Louisville Palace, 625 S. Fourth St.

COST: $29.50, $39.50, $45, available at the box office and online at www.livenation.com

Greg Martin (Photo: Scott Murphy )

The Greg Martin Group stars one of the world's great blues-rock guitarists in Martin, a member of the Kentucky HeadHunters and a devotee of American roots music. He's celebrating the release of a new 45, "Groovy Grubworm," and a vinyl bazaar starts at 6 p.m.

WHEN: 8:30 p.m. Nov. 12

WHERE: Tim Faulkner Gallery, 1512 Portland Ave.

COST: $10, $7 for Kentuckiana Blues Society Members

Futurebirds (Photo: Provided)

Of all the bands that feel tied to and influenced by My Morning Jacket, the Futurebirds really seem to get it right while exploring their own sound. The Georgia band spills out melody in rivers and its songs are incredibly light on their feet. Mike Adams at His Honest Weight opens.

WHEN: 9 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Zanzabar, 2100 S. Preston St.

COST: $10

Justin Townes Earle (Photo: Provided)

Justin Townes Earle released an acclaimed album in September called "Single Mothers," on which he explored some complicated relationships, not all of them with women. He's now working on "Absent Fathers," and he'll certainly have some material for that. Cory Branan opens.

WHEN: 9 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Headliners Music Hall, 1386 Lexington Road

COST: $20, ages 18 and up

The Kentuckiana Blues Society celebrates 26 years of enjoying and promoting the blues with a birthday party starring Chicago's Cash Box Kings, New York's Tas Cru & His Tortured Souls and Indiana's Sad Sam Blues Jam.

WHEN: 7 p.m. Saturday

WHERE: Headliners Music Hall, 1386 Lexington Road

COST: $10, free for KBS members, ages 18 and up.

Seluah (Photo: Provided)

Louisville's always arresting Seluah leads a parade of Kentucky music, joined by locals New Bravado and Lexington's Jovontaes. Expect a lot of guitars, not all of them used as blunt objects. Although that's going to happen.

WHEN: 10 p.m. Friday

WHERE: The New Vintage, 2126 S. Preston St.

COST: $7

(Photo: Krause, Johansen)

Miguel Zenon celebrates the release of a new album, "Identities Are Interchangeable," an exploration of cultural identity that focuses on New York City's Puerto Rican community. A jazz saxophonist with an international reputation, Zenon will perform with drummer Eric Doob, pianist Luis Perdomo and bassist Hans Glawischnig.

WHEN: 8 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Clifton Center, 2117 Payne St.

COST: $18
